JOB DESCRIPTIONS AND JOB EVALUATION
JOB DESCRIPTIONS
Each position within UPMC is required to have a job description. All job descriptions are
stored in HR Direct. When a manager proposes a new position or significant changes in an
existing one, it is the responsibility of the manager to write or revise the job description. The
job description template can be found on the Infonet. Managers should work with the business
unit human resources department in developing the job description and submitting changes.
The components of the job description include:
1. Job Purpose - summary of the general duties and responsibilities of the job;
2. Age-Specific Competencies - the age range of the patient population served (if applicable);
3. Minimum Job Requirements - the minimum level of education, experience, specialized
licensure/certification and knowledge that is required to perform the job;
4. Responsibilities - the major duties of the job; and
5. Physical Requirements - the physical demands of the job and environmental conditions.
JOB EVALUATION SYSTEM
The job evaluation process is intended to provide a consistent method for evaluating the value
of a job within UPMC. This process uses market data as the basis for determining the
appropriate salary range. If no market data is available, jobs are evaluated based upon a
comparison with similar jobs within UPMC. The factors used to evaluate the job are:
I. Knowledge and Skill
This factor considers the range of knowledge and skills required to perform the job
responsibilities. Knowledge and skill are evaluated for both technical and managerial content.
Experience, innate or trained skills, and formal knowledge are all recognized as potential
elements which contribute to an individual’s ability to do the job. Consideration should be
given to:
• The type of information that is processed;
• The complexity of the information;
• The depth of knowledge required;
• Required knowledge of a recognizable professional field; and
• Integrated knowledge of multiple fields.
Note: Care should be taken to consider the level of knowledge required by the job rather than
the “know-how” of the incumbent.
7

II. Problem Solving/Decision Making
This factor considers the degree to which judgment, analysis, and complexity must be
exercised in planning, investigating problems, and evaluating alternative solutions to the
problems posed by the job. This factor deals with the nature of the decisions, the variety of
problems and how decisions are made. This factor should also be evaluated in the context of
the “typical” issues of the job which are expected to be resolved. Consideration should be
given to:
• The complexity of the types of problems repeatedly encountered by the job;
• The availability of alternative solutions to the problems encountered;
• The amount of creativity and innovation required to make decisions;
• The degree to which decision making requires managing/taking risks; and
• The existence of resource persons or materials to assist with problem-solving activities.
Note: This factor should consider the context of the “typical” issues of the job which are
repeatedly encountered and expected to be resolved by the job.
III. Internal/External Contacts
This factor is concerned with the nature and frequency of interpersonal communication
required by the job. Considerations should be given to:
• The amount of persuasion and negotiation required;
• The complexity and sensitivity of information exchanged;
• The impact of the communication on the system/entity; and
• The types of people communicated to in the job.
Note: Particularly important is the level of skill required to communicate effectively during
regular job activities, not unusual situations.
IV. Scope of Responsibility
This factor is concerned with the degree of supervision received or exercised by the position.
The degree of planning, resource management, and organizing required by the position should
also be taken into account. Consideration should be given to:
• The position’s responsibility for determining work priorities and establishing work
schedules;
• The extent to which incumbents work independently on projects or programs; and
• The opportunity to influence results including the magnitude of costs/assets affected by
the job.
Once the job description is complete and approved, the job description should be forwarded to
the business unit human resources department for evaluation. The business unit human
resources representative will review the job description for accuracy and completeness. If the
job is a reclassification of an existing job, the human resources business unit representative will
submit the job description and a Job Evaluation Request to the Corporate Compensation
8

Department for review. The Corporate Compensation Department will review the proposed
range for market competitiveness and/or equity and comparability within UPMC.
SALARY STRUCTURE
Salary structures are established using a market-based approach. The salary structures are
based on market data in defined geographical areas. Please reach out to your HR
Representative regarding questions related to salary structures.
The salary structure provides the mechanism for relating the pay of each job to both market
pay levels and other job pay levels within the appropriate UPMC entity(s). The salary structure
contains separate pay grades with corresponding salary ranges. The market target of a salary
range reflects the market value of the job when compared to external organizations. Market
targets are developed by averaging clusters of similar market values for benchmark jobs. The
minimum and maximum salaries for each pay grade represent the available range limits of
salaries to be paid for jobs assigned to those pay grades.
COMPETITIVE MARKET ANALYSIS
Salary structures are reviewed on an annual basis for market competitiveness. Selected jobs
representing a comprehensive cross section of UPMC in terms of levels and functions, and for
which ample market salary information is available, are identified as benchmark positions.
Detailed market salary survey data is gathered for each benchmark job and used to determine
the competitive or market value. If appropriate and financially feasible, ranges are adjusted by
UPMC.
9

EXEMPT/NON-EXEMPT STATUS – FAIR LABOR STANDARDS ACT
Whether a position receives overtime or not is determined by the provisions of the Fair Labor
Standards Act (FLSA) and applicable state laws and regulations. During the evaluation
process, the duties of each position are reviewed using guidelines set forth by the FLSA and
state law.
Non-exempt positions are covered by the provisions of the FLSA and applicable state laws.
Accordingly, non-exempt employees must be paid for all hours worked including 1.5 times
their regular hourly rate if they work any time over 40 hours in a week.
Positions that are “exempt” within the meaning of the FLSA and/or applicable state law, are
not covered by the overtime provisions of the law(s). Exempt employees are paid a fixed
salary, regardless of the number of hours worked. This means that employees are paid a pre-
defined dollar amount per week that is not subject to a salary reduction due to the number of
hours worked. If an exempt employee works less than eight hours in a day, the employee
cannot be docked. For example, if a full-time exempt employee works five hours in a day, she
or he must be paid for the entire day. Accrued paid time off (PTO) or, if applicable, extended
ill time (EIB) can be used to offset the absence of partial hours. However, if the employee
does not have enough accrued time to offset the absence of partial hours, the employee must be
paid for the entire day. Docking of partial hours is a violation of the FLSA and will result in
the loss of the exemption and require overtime payment. This provision includes employees
who receive no overtime and employees who receive straight time for hours worked beyond
the end of the shift.
The employing UPMC entity is not required to pay the full salary in the initial or terminal
week of employment, or for weeks in which an exempt employee takes unpaid leave under the
Family and Medical Leave Act.
If you believe that a deduction which violates the FLSA (or state law) has been taken from
your paycheck, you can file your concerns with any of your business unit’s human resources
representatives. If your concerns are not resolved, you can escalate your concerns to the
compensation Director/Sr. Director in Corporate Services. If it is determined that an improper
deduction was made, UPMC will reimburse you for any lost wages.
Some exempt positions within UPMC receive straight time pay for hours over forty These
positions are covered by the salary no docking provision in the FLSA. These positions are
grandfathered from prior practices. No new positions will be added to this classification.
The business unit human resources department, in consultation with Corporate Compensation,
will determine the overtime status of each position using guidelines set forth by the FLSA.
10

HOURS WORKED (NON-EXEMPT EMPLOYEES)
Non-exempt employees must be paid for all hours worked. Non-exempt employees are
working when they are required to be on duty, on the employer’s premises, or at a prescribed
workplace. Time is considered worked time if the employee performs their regular duties at
home, is not substantially relieved of duties during lunch or works before or after their
designated schedule.
Regular work duties are those that an employee is hired to perform and include all activities
that are necessary to getting the job done. Activities such as computer logon/logoff, checking
email, voicemail, computer work, paperwork, etc., are considered hours worked if they are
needed for and essential to completing the job.
In addition to regularly scheduled work time, common examples of worked time include:
• taking authorized training courses from home;
• working through lunch;
• working before or after a scheduled shift;
• use of cell phones, mobile devices, laptop computers, computers at home, or
other electronic devices for remote work.
It is the responsibility of each non-exempt employee to accurately record their time daily via
the manner designated by the department. This includes properly recording in and out times at
the beginning and end of a shift, overriding automatic lunch deductions if working through
lunch or if interrupted during lunch (see Meal Periods). Employees must immediately notify
their supervisors if they are unable to properly record their time.
Under the FLSA, we are required to pay non-exempt employees for all work performed
whether at the employer’s worksite or when telecommuting/working from home. Therefore,
non-exempt employees must be paid for all hours of telework actually performed, including
overtime work, in accordance with the FLSA and/or state wage and hour law. UPMC
compensates non-exempt employees for all reported and unreported hours of telework that they
know or have reason to believe had been performed.
If you believe that your work hours have not been properly recorded, please contact your
departmental timekeeper or supervisor. If after discussions with your departmental timekeeper
or supervisor, you do not believe your time has been reported properly, you should contact
your business unit’s Human Resources department or the UPMC Compliance hotline: 1-877-
983-8442 so that an investigation can be initiated.
ADDITIONAL FLSA INFORMATION
For more details on the FLSA as it relates to UPMC, please refer to the FLSA pamphlet.

MERIT PROGRAM AND PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT
MERIT INCREASE GUIDELINES
Base pay is linked to performance through the merit program. Performance management is an
ongoing process. A 90-day check-in is required to be completed during the six-month
orientation period for those who are newly hired, rehired, and promoted. Employees’
performance is typically evaluated on an on-going basis throughout the performance year
through the anytime feedback tools included in HR Direct.
After the six-month orientation period, employees typically will be evaluated on an annual
basis thereafter and receive a merit increase if eligible. However, depending on when an
employee’s hire, rehire, or promotion date falls within the calendar year, the employee may not
be eligible for an annual evaluation and related merit increase. (See below for details.)
Merit budgets are determined annually, based on market conditions and UPMC’s economic
feasibility. The total of planned increases is governed by the merit increase budget established
each year in consultation with the UPMC senior leadership team. Merit increase guidelines are
intended to provide managers with general definitions of performance and the appropriate size
of individual increases. Overall consistent judgment on the part of the reviewer is an important
factor in administering salaries in a fair and equitable manner.
Regular full-time, flex full-time, regular part-time, job-share, limited part-time and casual
employees are eligible for merit increases; however, regular full-time, flex full-time and casual
employees who are paid at a common set rate receive performance reviews but are not eligible
for merit increases. Temporary employees are also reviewed but are not eligible for merit
increases.
The performance management system used throughout UPMC has five categories of
performance ratings:
• Deficient, Poor Performer
• Marginal Performer
• Solid/Strong/Good Performer
• Superior Performer
• Top Performer (Role Model)
The performance review and merit program has transitioned to a continuous performance
management cycle beginning in 2019. Employees eligible for a merit award based on their
2025 performance will receive their merit on a common review date in the May 2026
timeframe.
New hires and promoted employees will follow the merit pro-ration as follows:
January 2025 – September 2025:
The employee’s merit proration date would be based on their hire/promotion date, and they
will receive a pro-rated merit increase amount in May 2026.
12

October 2025 – December 2025:
An employee who is hired/promoted after October 2025 will receive a pro-rated merit increase
in May of 2027.
For additional information, please refer to the Infonet for the Performance Management
Resources and Merit Proration Guidelines.
SPECIAL RECOGNITION PROGRAM
UPMC’s Special Recognition Program allows lump-sum merit awards to be given to those
employees who are at the range maximum but less than 10% above range maximum.
Additionally, if an employee’s base rate is near the maximum of the salary range and the merit
exceeds the maximum of the range, the employee will receive a partial merit increase up to the
maximum of the range and a lump-sum merit award of the balance.
Example:
Employee A is a full-time employee who currently earns $28.00. The maximum of the range
is $28.29. The employee’s performance rating is Solid/Strong/Good Performer. The evaluation
recommends a 3.5% merit increase. The employee’s rate will increase to $28.29 (maximum of
the range), and the employee will also receive the remainder of the increase as a partial lump
sum merit award.
OTHER SALARY CHANGE GUIDELINES
Normally, new employees should be hired between the minimum and the market target of the
range. The exact position in the range will depend upon the employee’s relevant experience
and qualifications for the job. Consideration must be given to the new hire’s prior relevant
experience, other special qualifications they may have and internal department salary equity.
In general, new employees who meet the minimum qualifications of the job and have no
additional relevant experience above the minimum qualifications should be hired at the
minimum of the range or the established hiring rate, whichever is greater. Under no
circumstance will an employee be hired below the minimum of the range or the established
hiring rate.
As a guideline, new employees with relevant experience above the minimum qualifications of
the job will be given credit for relevant experience above the minimum qualifications generally
at a rate of 3.0% per year above the minimum or established hiring rate, up to the market target
of the range. Considerations must be given to internal salary equity.
For internal equity purposes and system-wide consistency in pay, all offers are made by
recruitment.
13

LEAVES OF ABSENCE
A merit eligible employee who is on a leave of absence when the merit process is administered
will receive their merit effective the first day of the pay period following the employee’s return
to work.
TRANSFERS WITHIN UPMC
I. Lateral transfer between two salary structures
If an employee transfers between structures (Pittsburgh to Southwest PA, Central PA to
Pittsburgh or vice versa) into a position with the same or similar job duties, an employee's
salary will be adjusted by the percentage difference between the market targets of the ranges
(see following examples). The maximum adjustment is 10%. However, no employee will
receive less than the minimum rate of the new pay grade or the established hiring rate. The
Vice President of Human Resources can modify the final offer of employment based upon
internal equity of the new department. The employee merit proration date will not change.
Use the following method to calculate the rate change for an employee who transfers between
pay structures:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target)
2. Add 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1
3. Multiply the employee’s current rate by this factor and apply any caps per current
guidelines
Example 1:
Employee A is a transporter at a business unit in the Pittsburgh structure. Employee A
earns $18.25 an hour and is interviewing for a transporter job at a business unit in the
Southwest PA structure.
The Pittsburgh and Southwest PA range market targets:
LOCATION HIRE MARKET
RATE TARGET*
Current Pittsburgh N/A $18.00
Future Southwest PA N/A $17.24
* Midpoint of Range
How to determine Employee A’s rate:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target).
($17.24 – $18.00) / $18.00 = -0.0422 or -4.22%
2. Subtract 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1: (1 – .0422 = 0.9578)
3. Multiply the employee’s current base rate by the difference: $18.25 x 0.9578 = $17.48
14

Example 2:
Employee B is a professional staff nurse at a business unit in the Southwest PA
structure. Employee B earns $33.00 an hour and is interviewing for a professional staff
nurse job at a business unit in the Pittsburgh structure.
The Pittsburgh and Southwest PA range market targets:
LOCATION HIRE MARKET
RATE TARGET*
Current Southwest PA $32.03 $34.50
Future Pittsburgh $32.55 $37.00
* Midpoint of Range
How to determine Employee B’s rate:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target).
($37.00 – $34.50) / $34.50 = 0.0725 or 7.25%
2. Add 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1: (1 + .0725 = 1.0725)
3. Multiply the employee’s current base rate by the difference: $33.00x 1.0725= $35.39
Example 3:
Employee C is a surgical technologist at a business unit in the Central PA structure.
Employee C earns $22.50 an hour and is interviewing for a surgical technologist job at
a business unit in the Pittsburgh structure.
The Central PA and Pittsburgh range market targets:
LOCATION HIRE MARKET
RATE TARGET*
Current Central PA $ 21.87 $24.80
Future Pittsburgh $ 21.20 $25.30
* Midpoint of Range
How to determine Employee C’s rate:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target).
($25.30– $24.80) / $24.80= 0.0202or 2.02%
2. Add 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1: (1 + .0202 =1.0202)

II. Lateral transfer within the same salary grade and structure
A lateral transfer is defined as a reclassification or move to a position within the same salary
structure and the same pay grade as the current job with a change in job duties. Staff members
who laterally transfer maintain their current pay rate. The Vice President of Human Resources
can modify the final offer of employment based upon internal equity of the new department.
The employee merit proration date will not change.
III. Promotion
A promotion is defined as a reclassification or a move to a position which is in a higher pay
grade than the current job with a change in job duties. Promotional increases range from 0 –
10%. However, no employee will receive less than the minimum rate of the new pay grade or
the established hiring rate. Additionally, no employee will receive an increase beyond the
maximum of the new range. Any exceptions via the recruitment process require Vice President
of Human Resources, or designee, approval. Exceptions outside of the recruitment process
require Human Resources business unit Vice President, or designee, approval.
Promotions are effective at the beginning of the next pay period following final approval of the
promotion. Promotions result in the change of the employee’s merit pro-ration date.
Promotions from January 2025 – September 2025:
The employee’s merit proration date would be based on their promotion date, and they will
receive a pro-rated merit increase amount in May 2026.
Promotions from October 2025 – December 2025:
An employee who is promoted after October 2025 will receive a pro-rated merit increase in
May of 2027.
IV. Demotion
A demotion is defined as a reclassification or move to a position which is in a lower pay grade
than the current job and there is a change in job duties. Salary reductions resulting from
demotions range from 0 – 10%. However, no employee will receive less than the minimum rate
of the new pay grade or the established hiring rate and no employee will receive more than the
maximum rate of the new pay grade.
V. Timing of the transfer
Transfers must occur at the beginning of a pay period and the transfer notice period should not
exceed four (4) weeks. During this transition period, the employee may work 100% at the
current facility, 100% at the new facility, or any amount in between. Extensions which result
in a transfer notification period beyond four (4) weeks and up to eight (8) weeks may be
granted by the Vice President of Human Resources, or their designee, to ensure continuity of
care while patients are moved to a new provider or in instances where governing agency
approvals are needed to finalize the transferring employee’s ability to perform the duties of the
new position.

OVERTIME

overtime for non-exempt staff. Exempt employees are not subject to the overtime provisions
of the FLSA and are paid on a salaried basis.
40 Hour Method
This method recognizes overtime when the worked hours in a week exceed 40 and treats the
two weeks in the payroll cycle separately.
Below is an example that shows how the 40-hour method is used to calculate overtime.
Example:
A staff member earning $20 an hour works the following schedule for one pay period:
S M T W T F S
Week 1 10 10 10 10 off off off
Week 2 off 8 8 8 8 8 off

$20 an hour.
In general, hours worked are included in calculating overtime and non-work time is not
included. The chart below shows hours that are included and excluded toward the
calculation of overtime.

minutes or more

MEAL PERIODS
Every attempt should be made to grant a 30-minute meal period for non-exempt employees.
Typically, this meal period is unpaid. However, meal periods MUST be counted as hours
worked and paid if the following conditions are not met:
• The meal period must be scheduled for 30 minutes
• The employee must receive 20 consecutive minutes of uninterrupted mealtime
• The employee is free to leave their workstation, unit, or area
An uninterrupted meal period is when an employee is completely relieved of ALL work
duties for at least 20 consecutive minutes.
Examples of an uninterrupted and unpaid meal period include:
• The employee spends 20 consecutive minutes in the cafeteria, break area, department
lunchroom, or other area (i.e., off site at a restaurant) and does not engage in any work-
related duties, or receive any work-related calls or pages, and then receives a work-
related call or a Code announcement requiring their attention before the meal break is
over.
• The employee chooses to remain at their workstation during their meal period but
spends at least 20 consecutive minutes surfing the internet, reading a magazine, or
doing nothing.
• The employee is in the cafeteria and receives a phone call during the first 5-minutes of
their meal period from a co-worker to answer a work-related question. She can resume
her meal break and is uninterrupted for the remainder of the meal break.
• The employee is in the cafeteria and receives a phone call on their cell phone during
their meal period from a friend, relative, or co-worker to discuss a personal, non-work-
related matter.
The time and attendance system (KRONOS) has an automatic feature that will deduct a 30-
minute meal period after 5 hours of time worked. Nonexempt employees must answer a
question whenever they swipe out at the end of the shift about whether they received an
uninterrupted meal period during the shift.
If an employee receives an uninterrupted meal period, answer “Yes” to the question on the
time clock and the meal period will be unpaid.
An interrupted meal period is when an employee must engage in ANY work-related activity
that prohibits him or her from having at least 20 consecutive minutes of work-free time.
Employees should not be interrupted during their meal period except in cases of medical
emergencies.
18

Examples of an interrupted meal period that should be paid include:
• The employee is in the cafeteria and receives a page during the meal period from a
physician or their supervisor asking the employee to return to their workstation. The
employee was not relieved from his/her duties for a minimum of 20 minutes during the
meal period.
• The employee is in the cafeteria and receives a phone call one minute into the meal
period from a physician, supervisor or co-worker asking a work-related question, or to
discuss a work-related issue and is unable to resume the meal period for a minimum of
20 minutes.
• The employee is in the department lunchroom for the meal period but spends the time
periodically answering work-related e-mails on a Blackberry or iPhone.
• The employee is in the department lunchroom for the meal period but spends the time
periodically answering calls on their “pickle phone”.
• The employee is required to remain at their workstation or unit at the request of the
employee’s supervisor during the meal period just in case a work-related issue should
arise.
If an employee is unable to receive a meal period, or if the employee’s meal period is
interrupted with work duties, answer “No” to the question on the time clock and the meal
period will be paid.
It is the employee’s responsibility to accurately answer an end of shift question if they work
through their meal period. Employees must immediately notify their supervisors if they are
unable to appropriately record their time.
Please refer to KRONOS resources for the timekeeping instructions.
19

STANDBY AND CALL-IN PAY
I. Standby Pay
Standby pay is provided when a staff member is required to be available for work while away
from UPMC premises. It is paid regardless of whether the staff member is called to work. To
qualify, the staff member must be able to be contacted immediately by a device (pager, email,
text, phone, etc.) (phone, text, email, pager, etc.) at which he or she can be reached directly and
must be able to begin work within the timeframe required by the department.
Non-exempt employees with an approved operational need are eligible for standby pay.
Employees cannot receive standby pay and regular or call-in pay for the same time. Standby
eligibility varies by business unit/department. Please contact your human resources
representative with questions about the standby rate for your business unit and/or eligibility for
standby pay.
II. Call-In Pay
Off Premises Call-in: Call-in pay is provided when a staff member is required to physically
report to duty at a UPMC location from standby status from off UPMC premises on a non-
scheduled shift. Employees called into a location while away from UPMC premises for non-
scheduled duty receive a minimum of two hours of call-in pay.
Remote Call-In: Call-in pay is provided when a staff member is required to perform regular
work duties from home or other non-UPMC location from standby status on a non-scheduled
shift. Employees called to work remotely (one or multiple times) while away from UPMC
premises for non-scheduled duty receive a minimum of one hour (in total not per instance) of
call-in pay.
Non-exempt employees with an approved operational need are eligible for call-in pay.
Employees receive one and one-half times their regular hourly rate for all hours worked on
call-in status. Employees cannot receive call-in pay and regular or standby pay for the same
time.
Employees required to stay immediately beyond their regular scheduled shift for coverage or to
complete work assignments are ineligible for call-in pay.
ACTING PAY
If a staff member is temporarily assigned to a higher position, which is at least one pay grade
higher than the current position and meet the qualifications of this higher position, for at least
one pay period, the staff member may be eligible for acting pay. Please contact your local
business unit human resources department to determine if acting pay is available at your
business unit and for specific information.
20

OFF-SHIFT DIFFERENTIALS
Off-shift differentials are paid to eligible non-exempt employees. Shift differentials apply to
all worked hours except call-in hours. Consecutive shifts are considered separate shifts for
shift differential purposes. UPMC has standardized off-shift differential based on job grade
and salary structure. Please contact your human resources representative for the off-shift
differential rates.
I. Eight- and Ten-Hour Shifts
Shift differentials apply to all hours of the shift (i.e., no partial hours) if:
• The shift starts on or after noon AND on or before 3:00 a.m.; AND
• The employee works four or more hours between 3 p.m. and 7 a.m.
II. Twelve-Hour Shifts
Shift differentials apply to all hours worked between 3 p.m. and 7 a.m. except shifts starting
between 4 a.m. and 11:59 a.m. If a shift starts between 4 a.m. and 11:59 a.m., differentials
apply only if six or more hours are worked beyond 3 p.m. Only the hours worked beyond 3
p.m. are eligible for shift differential. Please refer to Exhibit B for examples of when
differentials apply.
III. Shifts Less Than Eight Hours
Employees who work less than eight hours must work four or more hours between 3 p.m. and 7
a.m. to be eligible for shift differentials.
WEEKEND DIFFERENTIALS
There is no additional weekend differential. However, off-shift differentials apply to eligible
hours.
CHARGE DIFFERENTIALS
Charge differentials are paid to eligible non-exempt employees who are the designated charge
person for the shift. The charge rate varies by business unit. Please contact your human
resources representative for the charge differential for your business unit.
21

HOLIDAYS AND HOLIDAY PREMIUM
UPMC generally recognizes the following seven holidays:
 New Year’s Day
 Martin Luther King, Jr. Day
 Memorial Day
 Independence Day
 Labor Day
 Thanksgiving Day
 Christmas Day
• Regular full-time and flex full-time employees generally budgeted for 72-80 hours per
biweekly pay period (.9 – 1.0 FTE) are eligible to receive 8 hours of paid holiday time off
each holiday, regardless of their schedule.
• Flex full-time employees less than .90 FTE (.7) generally budgeted for 56 hours per
biweekly pay period will receive prorated holiday time off based on the budgeted FTE. For
example, a .7 FTE will receive 5.6 hours of holiday time off. Note: if a flex full-time
employee (.7) FTE works 8 hours on the holiday only the prorated amount of 5.6 hours of
Holiday time off will be placed in their PTO balance.
• Job-share employees are also eligible to receive paid holiday time off based on the standard
hours of the job.
• Holiday time off will be treated and utilized as PTO. Regular part-time, limited part-time,
temporary, weekend programs, and casual staff members are not eligible to receive paid
holiday time off. Total paid holiday time off cannot exceed 56 hours in a calendar year.
• Eligible weekend program participants may use up to a total of 96 hours of a combination
scheduled and unscheduled Paid Time Off (PTO) and Ill Time Off (ITO) on the weekends
for a maximum of eight weekend shifts off in a fiscal year. Holiday scheduling and work
requirements will mirror the department’s standard expectations for non-weekend staff.
• Eligible staff members that are off on a recognized UPMC Holiday will receive Holiday
Time Off Paid (HOF). Eligible staff members that work on a recognized UPMC Holiday
will have their eligible holiday time off loaded into a Holiday Unused PTO bank to be used
on their next taken PTO day (within the pay period that contains the holiday or after) or the
staff member can elect to have the holiday off time paid out in the pay period in which the
holiday occurs in lieu of banking.
• A staff member with an unauthorized absence on a scheduled workday immediately
preceding, on, or following a holiday is ineligible for holiday pay and will not have PTO
added to their PTO bank for the holiday.
22

• All staff (except director level and above) is eligible for the holiday premium of 1.5 times
pay if they work the holiday.
• Eight- and Ten-Hour Shifts
Holiday premium applies if the majority of hours in a shift are worked on the holiday
between 11 p.m. the day before the holiday and 11 p.m. the day of the holiday. Holiday
premium applies to all hours of the shift.
• Twelve-Hour Shifts
Holiday premium applies to all hours worked between 11 p.m. the day before the holiday
and 11 p.m. the day of the holiday.
Please see Exhibit C for examples of when holiday premium applies.
• If an actual holiday falls on a weekend (Saturday or Sunday), then the day before (Friday)
or the day after (Monday) is designated as the holiday. If an employee works on the
designated holiday (Friday or Monday) and not the actual holiday (Saturday or Sunday),
the employee will be paid a premium for hours worked on the designated holiday.
• If an employee works on the actual holiday (Saturday or Sunday) and not the designated
holiday (Friday or Monday), the employee will be paid a premium for the hours worked on
the actual holiday.
• If an employee works on both the actual holiday and the designated holiday, the employee
will be paid a premium for the day on which the greater number of hours are worked.
• If a regular full-time, flex full-time or job-share employee works on a holiday, in addition
to the holiday premium pay, the employee may choose another day off using the holiday
time added to the PTO balance or receive pay in lieu of the holiday time. To receive pay in
lieu of the holiday, a request is sent to the Payroll Department, with their manager’s
approval, in the pay period that includes the holiday.
• A staff member on a leave of absence is not eligible for holiday pay.
ADDITIONAL PTO INFORMATION can be found on the Infonet.
WORKWEEK
The workweek begins Sunday at 12:00 a.m. and ends Saturday at 11:59 p.m.
23

TIME ROUNDING
To ensure accurate and efficient processing of payroll and consistency with established pay
policies, an automated time and attendance system is used to record an employee’s time on
duty. All employees should use the automated time and attendance system (KRONOS).
Non-exempt employees should record shift start and end times through a time collection
method. The times non-exempt employees start and end their shifts are rounded in accordance
with the Fair Labors Standards Act (FLSA) within established pay policies.
Employees who are unscheduled (do not use the scheduling component of KRONOS) in the
time and attendance system have a six-minute time rounding rule for all times (punches) and
are paid according to the schedule below.
Unscheduled Method using KRONOS:
Punch in or out between: Paid to:
:58-:03 :00
:04-:09 :06
:10-:15 :12
:16-:21 :18
:22-:27 :24
:28-:33 :30
:34-:39 :36
:40-:45 :42
:46-:51 :48
:52-:57 :54
Scheduled Method using KRONOS:
Employees who are scheduled (use the scheduling component of KRONOS) in the time and
attendance system also have a six-minute time rounding rule for all times (punches) and are
paid according to the schedule above except at their scheduled start and end times. Employees
punching in or punching out five minutes before or five minutes after their scheduled shift are
paid (rounded) to their scheduled start or end times. Managers should make every effort to set-
up a schedule on KRONOS for all employees.
Example:
Employee scheduled in KRONOS - 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.:
Punch in: 6:55 a.m. - 7:05 a.m. Paid to 7:00 a.m. (scheduled start time)
Punch out: 3:25 p.m. - 3:35 p.m. Paid to 3:30 p.m. (scheduled end time)
24

MULTIPLE JOBS AND DUAL EMPLOYMENT
For purposes of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), Non-exempt employees who work in
multiple jobs within separate UPMC business units or within the same business unit but
different departments, must be paid overtime for hours worked in excess of 40 hours per week.
Example:
A registered nurse works full-time at UPMC Presbyterian. The same nurse also works
additional hours at UPMC Mercy. The nurse is a non-exempt employee. During a
particular workweek the nurse works 40 hours at UPMC Presbyterian AND four additional
hours at UPMC Mercy.
All hours worked are considered as one employment for FLSA pay purposes. In this case,
the employee worked 44 hours during the workweek and must be paid overtime. The
employee will be paid 40 regular hours and four overtime hours. Managers should consult
their business unit human resources department prior to allowing multiple job work
arrangements.
OTHER PAY PRACTICES
Other policies which relate to compensation, but are not included in this manual, can be found
on the UPMC Infonet (http://infonet.upmc.edu/). Some of these policies are:
• Paid Time Off (PTO)
• Military Leave
• FMLA
• Personal Leave
• Parental Leave
• Paid Parental Leave (PPLOA)
• Funeral Leave
• Jury Duty
INCENTIVE/COMMISSION PLANS
Any incentive plan must be reviewed for approval per established guidelines with HR in
advance. Payments requested for unauthorized plans will be denied and any individuals not
adhering to the guidelines of this policy may be subject to the provisions of the Corrective
Action and Discharge policy (HS-HR0704). If you are considering an incentive plan, please
contact your local HR Department.

EXHIBIT A
JOB EVALUATION REQUEST
The purpose of a Job Evaluation Request is to provide information needed to complete an
analysis of a new or changed job and determine the job’s salary range. Job information is
provided by the Business Unit manager and Human Resources Representative. The
information provided is reviewed and analyzed by Compensation. After review, Compensation
will make the final determination regarding the job’s salary range and other job attributes.
Fields/Information needed to complete a job evaluation include:
• Job Family
• Job Function
• Management Level
• Salary Structure
• Comparator Job Code/s
• Occupational Classification
• Proposed Salary Grade
• Hiring Rate if applicable
• Weekend and/or Night Program if applicable
• Off-Shift Differential if applicable
• GL Account
• FLSA Overtime Status
• Accrual Schedules
• NLRB Category
• EEO1 Category
• EEO Job Group
• Survey Group
• Employee Health Physical Package
• Environmental Conditions
• Physical Conditions
• Licenses & Certifications
• Attached Job Description and Org Chart

GLOSSARY
Base wage rate (or base rate) - The hourly rate or salary paid for a job performed. Does not
include shift differentials, benefits, overtime, incentive premiums, or any pay element other than
the base rate.
Benchmark - A standard job with characteristics so detailed that other jobs can be compared as
being above, below, or comparable to it. Most frequently in compensation, benchmark refers to a
job or group of jobs used for making pay comparisons, either within the organization or to
comparable jobs outside the organization.
Bonus earnings (or bonus) - Any direct additional lump-sum payment made on top of a base
salary for either an individual or group.
Call-in pay - A guarantee of pay for a minimum of hours when employees are called to work from
standby status. Employees receive pay for at least the minimum number of hours established,
even if they do not work that number of hours.
Classification (job classification) - A hierarchical structure of jobs usually arranged into classes or
pay grades according to some form of job evaluation.
Compa-ratio - The ratio of an actual pay rate (numerator) to the market target for the respective
pay grade (denominator). Compa-ratios are used primarily to compare an individual’s actual rate
of pay to the market target or some other control point of the structure. A compa-ratio can be
calculated for a group of people, a department, or an entire organization.
Compensable factor - Any factor used to provide a basis for comparing job content in a job-
evaluation scheme. The commonly employed compensable factors include knowledge and skill,
problem solving and decision making, internal/external contacts and scope of responsibility.
Compensation strategy (compensation philosophy, policy) - The principles guiding the
compensation program. Strategy implies that compensation programs (both pay and benefits)
support organizational missions and goals in some way.
Competitive pay policy - The strategic decision an organization makes about pay levels. Some
organizations choose to pay a predetermined percentage above the market while other opt to pay
at market or even below. Choice of comparison labor market also is part of competitive pay
policy. Many organizations choose a geographic labor market for comparison, especially for
lower-level jobs. Others choose their product-market competitors as the comparison labor
market. Competitive pay policy is independent of structural policies such as lead, lag, or lead/lag
policies.
Compression - Pay differentials too small to be considered equitable. The term may apply to
differences between (1) the pay of supervisors and staff, (2) the pay of experienced and newly
hired incumbents of the same job, and (3) pay-range market targets in successive job grades.
33

Direct compensation - All forms of compensation that involve direct and immediate payment to
the individual – often including a base wage or salary payment.
Downgrading - The movement of a job to a lower level in a job-evaluation system or to a lower
job grade or pay range.
Equity - Anything earned through the provision or investment of something of value. In the case
of compensation, an employee earns equity interest through the provision of labor on a job. So
defined, equity often is used as a fairness criterion in compensation. People should be paid
according to their contributions.
Exempt - A term referring to those groups of employees that are exempt from the overtime
provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act. These groups may include executives, administrative
employees, professional employees, and those engaged in outside sales.
Exempt job - A job not subject to the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, with respect to
minimum wage and overtime.
External equity - A fairness criterion that provides a guideline for an employer to pay a wage that
corresponds to rates prevailing in external markets for an employee’s occupation.
Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 (FLSA) - A federal law governing minimum wage, overtime
pay, equal pay for men and women in the same jobs, child labor, and record-keeping
requirements.
Geographic differentials - Pay differentials established for the same job, based on differences in
cost of living or cost of labor between or among two or more geographical areas.
Hiring bonus - A lump sum provided at the time of hire to provide extra enticement to accept a
job offer.
Hiring rate - As a matter of wage policy, the beginning rate at which people who meet the
minimum qualifications for the position are hired into a job. Hiring rates are only used where the
market dictates an entry rate above the range minimum.
Incentive compensation - Any form of compensation designed to motivate or incentivize employees
to produce specified outputs or behave in a specified way, and to reward them for having done so.
Individual equity - A fairness criterion that provides a guideline to employers to set wage rates for
individual employees (people in the same job, in the simplest case) according to individual
variation in merit.
Individual pay rate - The rate of pay assigned to a given individual. Individual pay rates may vary
for the same job, as a function of time and grade, performance, or some other basis for
establishing variation in the employee’s merit.
Internal equity - A fairness criterion that directs an employer to set wage rates that correspond to
each job’s relative value to the organization.
34

Job description - A summary of the most important features of a job, including the general nature
of the work performed, specific task responsibilities, and the employee characteristics required to
perform the job. As one of the major outputs of job analysis, a job description should describe
and focus on the job itself, and not on any specific individual who might fill the job.
Job evaluation - A formal process by which management determines the relative value to be
placed on various jobs within the organization. The end result of job evaluation consists of an
assignment of jobs to a hierarchy of grades or some other hierarchical index of job value. Job
evaluation is most closely associated with the criterion of internal equity.
Job grade - One of the classes, levels or groups into which jobs of the same or similar value are
grouped for compensation purposes. Usually, all jobs in a grade have the same pay range:
maximum, minimum and market target.
Lump-sum bonus - An incentive reward which is awarded in a single cash payment.
Market pricing - A wage-and-salary policy that sets the rates to be paid for a job to the
organization’s best estimate of the going wage rate in the external marketplace for that job.
Estimates of what the market would pay for a job, based on what it pays for similar jobs, are used
to price jobs for which market data are not available. (See external equity.)
Market rates - The employer’s best estimate of the wage rates in the external labor market for a
given job or occupation.
Market target – Reflects the market value of the job when compared to external organizations.
Market targets are developed by averaging clusters of similar market values for benchmark jobs.
Mean (arithmetic mean) - A simple arithmetic average obtained by adding a set of numbers and
then dividing the sum by the number of items in the set.
Median - The middle item in a set of numbers containing an odd number of items, when the
numbers are ranked from high to low. When an even number of items are ranked from high to
low, the average of the two middle items is the median.
Merit increase - An adjustment to individual salary based on performance, or some other
individual equity basis.
Merit Proration Date - This is a date that coincides with the effective date of a hire/rehire or
promotion event, which establishes the appropriate continuous performance management
discussion assignments and merit award-eligibility.
Merit rating - A method for appraising the performance of an employee with respect to their job.
It frequently serves as a basis for making pay adjustments, promotion decisions, or work
reassignments.
Non-exempt employees - Employees who are subject to the minimum wage and overtime pay
provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
35

Overtime - Under the Fair Labor Standards Act, non-exempt employees must be paid one-and-
one-half times their normal wage rates for all hours worked in excess of 40 in any work week.
Pay range - The range of pay rates, from minimum to maximum, set for a pay grade or class.
Used as a policy for setting individual employee pay or salary rates.
Performance review - Any system of determining how well an individual employee has
performed during a period of time. Frequently used as a basis for determining merit increases.
Premium pay - Extra pay, beyond the regular wage rate, for work performed outside or beyond
regularly scheduled work periods, for example, holidays, night shifts, etc.
Range - (1) In a set of data, the difference between the maximum value and the minimum value.
(2) In a pay grade, the percentage by which the maximum pay exceeds the minimum. Sometimes
referred to as the range spread.
Range = [Maximum – Minimum) X 100] / Minimum
Salary - Compensation paid by the week, month or year (rather than per hour). Generally, this
applies to non-production, non-routine or supervisory jobs that are exempt from the provisions of
the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Salary budget - An amount or pool of money allocated for payment of salaries during a specified
period. Salary budgets must be considered when planning wage structure adjustments or
individual employee adjustments.
Shift differentials - Extra pay allowances made to employees who work on a shift other than a
regular day shift if the shift is thought to represent a hardship, or if competitive organizations
provide a similar premium.
Slotting - The act of placing a job into a category or classification defined by a job-evaluation
system. Slotting usually involves the comparison of a job to a particular standard or benchmark
job.
Total cash compensation - The total cash payment made to an individual in the form of
compensation in a given year.
Total rewards - The complete reward package for employees, including all forms of money,
benefits, services and in-kind payments.
Wage survey - A survey of a labor market to determine the going rates for benchmark jobs.
36

Every UPMC employing legal entity is an equal opportunity employer. UPMC policy prohibits

sex, genetics, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, marital status, familial status,
disability, veteran status, or any other legally protected group status. Further, UPMC will continue

GENERAL INFORMATION
OUR MISSION
UPMC’s mission is to serve our community by providing outstanding patient care and to shape
tomorrow’s health system through clinical and technological innovation, research, and
education.
OUR VISION
UPMC will lead the transformation of health care. The UPMC model will be nationally
recognized for redefining health care by:
Putting our patients, health plan members, employees, and community at the center of
everything we do and creating a model that ensures that every patient gets the right care, in the
right way, at the right time, every time.
Harnessing our integrated capabilities to deliver both superb state-of-the-art care to our patients
and high value to our stakeholders.
Employing our partnership with the University of Pittsburgh to advance the understanding of
disease, its prevention, treatment and cure.
Serving the underserved and disadvantaged, and advancing excellence and innovation
throughout health care.
Fueling the development of new businesses globally that are consistent with our mission as an
ongoing catalyst and driver of economic development for the benefit of the residents of the
region.
OUR VALUES
We create a safe environment where quality is our guiding principle.
Quality & Safety
We treat all individuals with dignity and respect.
Dignity & Respect
We listen to and care for our patients, our health plan members, our fellow employees,
our physicians, and our community.
Caring & Listening
We perform our work with the highest levels of responsibility and integrity.
Responsibility & Integrity
We think creatively and build excellence into everything that we do.
Excellence & Innovation

TOTAL REWARDS PHILOSOPHY
In support of UPMC’s mission and vision, UPMC is committed to providing a total rewards
program which is flexible enough to meet the unique needs of the businesses that make up the
health system while also supporting the objectives of UPMC as an integrated health system.
These programs are designed, in the aggregate, to support a prominent integrated health care
delivery and financing system with best-of-class quality of care and service through a focus on
health needs, exceptional citizenship and stewardship, while maintaining and improving
academic status through research and academic programs.
Accordingly, UPMC provides a total rewards program that is market competitive, fair and
provides the opportunity and challenge to share the system’s financial success both up and
down. All programs support UPMC’s organizational mission as a not-for-profit entity. The
program is designed to attract, motivate and retain outstanding staff members who demonstrate
the following attributes and organizational behaviors:
• Strong customer service orientation;
• Performance/results orientation;
• Accountability;
• Personal integrity and professionalism;
• Team orientation;
• Aligns success with that of all stakeholders;
• Commitment to continuous quality improvement; and
• Other competencies/behaviors deemed critical by the organization as outlined in the
performance management tool.
TOTAL REWARDS POLICY
At UPMC, an employee’s total rewards consist of:
• Compensation – Competitive pay for the work employees do – base pay, merit,
and premium pay
• Benefits – Assistance and security to meet the current and future needs of
employees and their families
• Performance and Recognition – Rewards for performance that supports the
goals and mission of UPMC
• Work-Life Balance – Balance to meet the important elements in the employee’s
life
• Development and Career Opportunities – Opportunities for each employee to
reach their career goals through continued learning and/or advancement
On an ongoing basis, UPMC reviews all these elements to make sure they are competitive.
The compensation standards of UPMC’s competitors are analyzed/benchmarked regularly as
part of the annual business planning process.
4

Throughout UPMC, employees are compensated based on their performance and contribution
to the accomplishment of the system, business unit and their individual objectives and to
provide incentives toward individual growth through a merit increase program.
The programs for all staff members provide forms of compensation that vary and are leveraged
based on organizational responsibility and performance, including individual and operational
elements with a strong orientation toward quality, customer service and appropriate financial
measures.
All programs are developed and administered in such a manner to fulfill UPMC’s commitment
to nondiscrimination with regard to race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, age, sex,
genetics, sexual orientation, gender expression, gender identity, or marital, familial, or
disability status or status as a protected Veteran or any other legally protected group status.
BASIC ELEMENTS – COMPENSATION PROGRAM
The basic elements of the UPMC Compensation Program are:
1. Base Salary
The level of base salary paid to all staff members is determined based on organizational
responsibility, performance, experience and other factors as may be reasonably considered.
Generally, base salary structure(s) are positioned at the middle of the appropriate competitive
markets. Certain mission-critical positions and market conditions may warrant that this
position be modified by UPMC from time to time.
The basis for determining the relative values of UPMC’s various jobs is a combination of
market pricing and the relative internal importance of the job, with market pricing being the
more dominant influence (i.e., relative job value will be established in a manner which reflects
marketplace realities). However, both factors used to determine relative job values are applied
consistently by UPMC in a manner which will not discriminate against any employee.
The primary marketplace in which UPMC has presence is the western Pennsylvania health care
market, taking into consideration the various geographical differentials adjusted for operational
scope metrics and complexity. The following salary structures have been identified by UPMC
and are considered unless market conditions dictate otherwise. These structures have been
updated with a new naming convention that is based on market data in the defined
geographical areas we serve:
• Pittsburgh – Encompasses large “Urban” cities
• Southwest PA, Western PA, and Western Maryland – Includes suburban or
community and regional settings
• Central & North Central PA - Central PA locations
• Southwest NY – Includes the Southwest NY locations
• West Central PA – Includes locations significantly East of Pittsburgh but not yet in
Central PA
5

Line-of-business variations are also considered. For positions which are not specific to the
health care industry (e.g., information technology, finance, etc.), the relevant marketplace(s)
are expanded to encompass such organizations and locations as are deemed to be appropriate.
The annual salary increase budget is based on such factors as UPMC performance, general
economic conditions, marketplace compensation trends and the existing appropriateness of
aggregate individual salary and pay levels. Actual annual salary adjustments are primarily
based upon individual performance, but may include other factors, which the market may
dictate.
Employee promotions and demotions are accompanied by appropriate salary adjustments in
accordance with established salary administration guidelines as outlined in later sections of this
manual.
2. Benefits
Benefit programs are designed to meet competitive target market levels. Target markets may
vary by line of business, geographic location, and employee group.
The benefit program shares a common platform while providing for variable levels of
contributions/cost. The benefit program supports the fulfillment of personal and family needs.
All benefit programs are fully and effectively communicated to all employees. Voluntary
benefits, which provide access, but not necessarily cost to the system, are designed to meet the
diverse needs of our workforce.
3. Merit / Performance Management
Additional details are included in the below section of “MERIT PROGRAM AND
PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT”
4. Job Evaluation
Additional details are included in the below section of “JOB DESCRIPTIONS AND JOB
EVALUATION”

JOB DESCRIPTIONS AND JOB EVALUATION
JOB DESCRIPTIONS
Each position within UPMC is required to have a job description. All job descriptions are
stored in HR Direct. When a manager proposes a new position or significant changes in an
existing one, it is the responsibility of the manager to write or revise the job description. The
job description template can be found on the Infonet. Managers should work with the business
unit human resources department in developing the job description and submitting changes.
The components of the job description include:
1. Job Purpose - summary of the general duties and responsibilities of the job;
2. Age-Specific Competencies - the age range of the patient population served (if applicable);
3. Minimum Job Requirements - the minimum level of education, experience, specialized
licensure/certification and knowledge that is required to perform the job;
4. Responsibilities - the major duties of the job; and
5. Physical Requirements - the physical demands of the job and environmental conditions.
JOB EVALUATION SYSTEM
The job evaluation process is intended to provide a consistent method for evaluating the value
of a job within UPMC. This process uses market data as the basis for determining the
appropriate salary range. If no market data is available, jobs are evaluated based upon a
comparison with similar jobs within UPMC. The factors used to evaluate the job are:
I. Knowledge and Skill
This factor considers the range of knowledge and skills required to perform the job
responsibilities. Knowledge and skill are evaluated for both technical and managerial content.
Experience, innate or trained skills, and formal knowledge are all recognized as potential
elements which contribute to an individual’s ability to do the job. Consideration should be
given to:
• The type of information that is processed;
• The complexity of the information;
• The depth of knowledge required;
• Required knowledge of a recognizable professional field; and
• Integrated knowledge of multiple fields.
Note: Care should be taken to consider the level of knowledge required by the job rather than
the “know-how” of the incumbent.
7

II. Problem Solving/Decision Making
This factor considers the degree to which judgment, analysis, and complexity must be
exercised in planning, investigating problems, and evaluating alternative solutions to the
problems posed by the job. This factor deals with the nature of the decisions, the variety of
problems and how decisions are made. This factor should also be evaluated in the context of
the “typical” issues of the job which are expected to be resolved. Consideration should be
given to:
• The complexity of the types of problems repeatedly encountered by the job;
• The availability of alternative solutions to the problems encountered;
• The amount of creativity and innovation required to make decisions;
• The degree to which decision making requires managing/taking risks; and
• The existence of resource persons or materials to assist with problem-solving activities.
Note: This factor should consider the context of the “typical” issues of the job which are
repeatedly encountered and expected to be resolved by the job.
III. Internal/External Contacts
This factor is concerned with the nature and frequency of interpersonal communication
required by the job. Considerations should be given to:
• The amount of persuasion and negotiation required;
• The complexity and sensitivity of information exchanged;
• The impact of the communication on the system/entity; and
• The types of people communicated to in the job.
Note: Particularly important is the level of skill required to communicate effectively during
regular job activities, not unusual situations.
IV. Scope of Responsibility
This factor is concerned with the degree of supervision received or exercised by the position.
The degree of planning, resource management, and organizing required by the position should
also be taken into account. Consideration should be given to:
• The position’s responsibility for determining work priorities and establishing work
schedules;
• The extent to which incumbents work independently on projects or programs; and
• The opportunity to influence results including the magnitude of costs/assets affected by
the job.
Once the job description is complete and approved, the job description should be forwarded to
the business unit human resources department for evaluation. The business unit human
resources representative will review the job description for accuracy and completeness. If the
job is a reclassification of an existing job, the human resources business unit representative will
submit the job description and a Job Evaluation Request to the Corporate Compensation
8

Department for review. The Corporate Compensation Department will review the proposed
range for market competitiveness and/or equity and comparability within UPMC.
SALARY STRUCTURE
Salary structures are established using a market-based approach. The salary structures are
based on market data in defined geographical areas. Please reach out to your HR
Representative regarding questions related to salary structures.
The salary structure provides the mechanism for relating the pay of each job to both market
pay levels and other job pay levels within the appropriate UPMC entity(s). The salary structure
contains separate pay grades with corresponding salary ranges. The market target of a salary
range reflects the market value of the job when compared to external organizations. Market
targets are developed by averaging clusters of similar market values for benchmark jobs. The
minimum and maximum salaries for each pay grade represent the available range limits of
salaries to be paid for jobs assigned to those pay grades.
COMPETITIVE MARKET ANALYSIS
Salary structures are reviewed on an annual basis for market competitiveness. Selected jobs
representing a comprehensive cross section of UPMC in terms of levels and functions, and for
which ample market salary information is available, are identified as benchmark positions.
Detailed market salary survey data is gathered for each benchmark job and used to determine
the competitive or market value. If appropriate and financially feasible, ranges are adjusted by
UPMC.
9

EXEMPT/NON-EXEMPT STATUS – FAIR LABOR STANDARDS ACT
Whether a position receives overtime or not is determined by the provisions of the Fair Labor
Standards Act (FLSA) and applicable state laws and regulations. During the evaluation
process, the duties of each position are reviewed using guidelines set forth by the FLSA and
state law.
Non-exempt positions are covered by the provisions of the FLSA and applicable state laws.
Accordingly, non-exempt employees must be paid for all hours worked including 1.5 times
their regular hourly rate if they work any time over 40 hours in a week.
Positions that are “exempt” within the meaning of the FLSA and/or applicable state law, are
not covered by the overtime provisions of the law(s). Exempt employees are paid a fixed
salary, regardless of the number of hours worked. This means that employees are paid a pre-
defined dollar amount per week that is not subject to a salary reduction due to the number of
hours worked. If an exempt employee works less than eight hours in a day, the employee
cannot be docked. For example, if a full-time exempt employee works five hours in a day, she
or he must be paid for the entire day. Accrued paid time off (PTO) or, if applicable, extended
ill time (EIB) can be used to offset the absence of partial hours. However, if the employee
does not have enough accrued time to offset the absence of partial hours, the employee must be
paid for the entire day. Docking of partial hours is a violation of the FLSA and will result in
the loss of the exemption and require overtime payment. This provision includes employees
who receive no overtime and employees who receive straight time for hours worked beyond
the end of the shift.
The employing UPMC entity is not required to pay the full salary in the initial or terminal
week of employment, or for weeks in which an exempt employee takes unpaid leave under the
Family and Medical Leave Act.
If you believe that a deduction which violates the FLSA (or state law) has been taken from
your paycheck, you can file your concerns with any of your business unit’s human resources
representatives. If your concerns are not resolved, you can escalate your concerns to the
compensation Director/Sr. Director in Corporate Services. If it is determined that an improper
deduction was made, UPMC will reimburse you for any lost wages.
Some exempt positions within UPMC receive straight time pay for hours over forty These
positions are covered by the salary no docking provision in the FLSA. These positions are
grandfathered from prior practices. No new positions will be added to this classification.
The business unit human resources department, in consultation with Corporate Compensation,
will determine the overtime status of each position using guidelines set forth by the FLSA.
10

HOURS WORKED (NON-EXEMPT EMPLOYEES)
Non-exempt employees must be paid for all hours worked. Non-exempt employees are
working when they are required to be on duty, on the employer’s premises, or at a prescribed
workplace. Time is considered worked time if the employee performs their regular duties at
home, is not substantially relieved of duties during lunch or works before or after their
designated schedule.
Regular work duties are those that an employee is hired to perform and include all activities
that are necessary to getting the job done. Activities such as computer logon/logoff, checking
email, voicemail, computer work, paperwork, etc., are considered hours worked if they are
needed for and essential to completing the job.
In addition to regularly scheduled work time, common examples of worked time include:
• taking authorized training courses from home;
• working through lunch;
• working before or after a scheduled shift;
• use of cell phones, mobile devices, laptop computers, computers at home, or
other electronic devices for remote work.
It is the responsibility of each non-exempt employee to accurately record their time daily via
the manner designated by the department. This includes properly recording in and out times at
the beginning and end of a shift, overriding automatic lunch deductions if working through
lunch or if interrupted during lunch (see Meal Periods). Employees must immediately notify
their supervisors if they are unable to properly record their time.
Under the FLSA, we are required to pay non-exempt employees for all work performed
whether at the employer’s worksite or when telecommuting/working from home. Therefore,
non-exempt employees must be paid for all hours of telework actually performed, including
overtime work, in accordance with the FLSA and/or state wage and hour law. UPMC
compensates non-exempt employees for all reported and unreported hours of telework that they
know or have reason to believe had been performed.
If you believe that your work hours have not been properly recorded, please contact your
departmental timekeeper or supervisor. If after discussions with your departmental timekeeper
or supervisor, you do not believe your time has been reported properly, you should contact
your business unit’s Human Resources department or the UPMC Compliance hotline: 1-877-
983-8442 so that an investigation can be initiated.
ADDITIONAL FLSA INFORMATION
For more details on the FLSA as it relates to UPMC, please refer to the FLSA pamphlet.

MERIT PROGRAM AND PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT
MERIT INCREASE GUIDELINES
Base pay is linked to performance through the merit program. Performance management is an
ongoing process. A 90-day check-in is required to be completed during the six-month
orientation period for those who are newly hired, rehired, and promoted. Employees’
performance is typically evaluated on an on-going basis throughout the performance year
through the anytime feedback tools included in HR Direct.
After the six-month orientation period, employees typically will be evaluated on an annual
basis thereafter and receive a merit increase if eligible. However, depending on when an
employee’s hire, rehire, or promotion date falls within the calendar year, the employee may not
be eligible for an annual evaluation and related merit increase. (See below for details.)
Merit budgets are determined annually, based on market conditions and UPMC’s economic
feasibility. The total of planned increases is governed by the merit increase budget established
each year in consultation with the UPMC senior leadership team. Merit increase guidelines are
intended to provide managers with general definitions of performance and the appropriate size
of individual increases. Overall consistent judgment on the part of the reviewer is an important
factor in administering salaries in a fair and equitable manner.
Regular full-time, flex full-time, regular part-time, job-share, limited part-time and casual
employees are eligible for merit increases; however, regular full-time, flex full-time and casual
employees who are paid at a common set rate receive performance reviews but are not eligible
for merit increases. Temporary employees are also reviewed but are not eligible for merit
increases.
The performance management system used throughout UPMC has five categories of
performance ratings:
• Deficient, Poor Performer
• Marginal Performer
• Solid/Strong/Good Performer
• Superior Performer
• Top Performer (Role Model)
The performance review and merit program has transitioned to a continuous performance
management cycle beginning in 2019. Employees eligible for a merit award based on their
2025 performance will receive their merit on a common review date in the May 2026
timeframe.
New hires and promoted employees will follow the merit pro-ration as follows:
January 2025 – September 2025:
The employee’s merit proration date would be based on their hire/promotion date, and they
will receive a pro-rated merit increase amount in May 2026.
12

October 2025 – December 2025:
An employee who is hired/promoted after October 2025 will receive a pro-rated merit increase
in May of 2027.
For additional information, please refer to the Infonet for the Performance Management
Resources and Merit Proration Guidelines.
SPECIAL RECOGNITION PROGRAM
UPMC’s Special Recognition Program allows lump-sum merit awards to be given to those
employees who are at the range maximum but less than 10% above range maximum.
Additionally, if an employee’s base rate is near the maximum of the salary range and the merit
exceeds the maximum of the range, the employee will receive a partial merit increase up to the
maximum of the range and a lump-sum merit award of the balance.
Example:
Employee A is a full-time employee who currently earns $28.00. The maximum of the range
is $28.29. The employee’s performance rating is Solid/Strong/Good Performer. The evaluation
recommends a 3.5% merit increase. The employee’s rate will increase to $28.29 (maximum of
the range), and the employee will also receive the remainder of the increase as a partial lump
sum merit award.
OTHER SALARY CHANGE GUIDELINES
Normally, new employees should be hired between the minimum and the market target of the
range. The exact position in the range will depend upon the employee’s relevant experience
and qualifications for the job. Consideration must be given to the new hire’s prior relevant
experience, other special qualifications they may have and internal department salary equity.
In general, new employees who meet the minimum qualifications of the job and have no
additional relevant experience above the minimum qualifications should be hired at the
minimum of the range or the established hiring rate, whichever is greater. Under no
circumstance will an employee be hired below the minimum of the range or the established
hiring rate.
As a guideline, new employees with relevant experience above the minimum qualifications of
the job will be given credit for relevant experience above the minimum qualifications generally
at a rate of 3.0% per year above the minimum or established hiring rate, up to the market target
of the range. Considerations must be given to internal salary equity.
For internal equity purposes and system-wide consistency in pay, all offers are made by
recruitment.
13

LEAVES OF ABSENCE
A merit eligible employee who is on a leave of absence when the merit process is administered
will receive their merit effective the first day of the pay period following the employee’s return
to work.
TRANSFERS WITHIN UPMC
I. Lateral transfer between two salary structures
If an employee transfers between structures (Pittsburgh to Southwest PA, Central PA to
Pittsburgh or vice versa) into a position with the same or similar job duties, an employee's
salary will be adjusted by the percentage difference between the market targets of the ranges
(see following examples). The maximum adjustment is 10%. However, no employee will
receive less than the minimum rate of the new pay grade or the established hiring rate. The
Vice President of Human Resources can modify the final offer of employment based upon
internal equity of the new department. The employee merit proration date will not change.
Use the following method to calculate the rate change for an employee who transfers between
pay structures:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target)
2. Add 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1
3. Multiply the employee’s current rate by this factor and apply any caps per current
guidelines
Example 1:
Employee A is a transporter at a business unit in the Pittsburgh structure. Employee A
earns $18.25 an hour and is interviewing for a transporter job at a business unit in the
Southwest PA structure.
The Pittsburgh and Southwest PA range market targets:
LOCATION HIRE MARKET
RATE TARGET*
Current Pittsburgh N/A $18.00
Future Southwest PA N/A $17.24
* Midpoint of Range
How to determine Employee A’s rate:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target).
($17.24 – $18.00) / $18.00 = -0.0422 or -4.22%
2. Subtract 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1: (1 – .0422 = 0.9578)
3. Multiply the employee’s current base rate by the difference: $18.25 x 0.9578 = $17.48
14

Example 2:
Employee B is a professional staff nurse at a business unit in the Southwest PA
structure. Employee B earns $33.00 an hour and is interviewing for a professional staff
nurse job at a business unit in the Pittsburgh structure.
The Pittsburgh and Southwest PA range market targets:
LOCATION HIRE MARKET
RATE TARGET*
Current Southwest PA $32.03 $34.50
Future Pittsburgh $32.55 $37.00
* Midpoint of Range
How to determine Employee B’s rate:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target).
($37.00 – $34.50) / $34.50 = 0.0725 or 7.25%
2. Add 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1: (1 + .0725 = 1.0725)
3. Multiply the employee’s current base rate by the difference: $33.00x 1.0725= $35.39
Example 3:
Employee C is a surgical technologist at a business unit in the Central PA structure.
Employee C earns $22.50 an hour and is interviewing for a surgical technologist job at
a business unit in the Pittsburgh structure.
The Central PA and Pittsburgh range market targets:
LOCATION HIRE MARKET
RATE TARGET*
Current Central PA $ 21.87 $24.80
Future Pittsburgh $ 21.20 $25.30
* Midpoint of Range
How to determine Employee C’s rate:
1. Determine the % difference between the market targets (subtract the new market target
from the current market target and divide by the current market target).
($25.30– $24.80) / $24.80= 0.0202or 2.02%
2. Add 1 to the factor calculated in Step 1: (1 + .0202 =1.0202)
